Dormitory men will soon be eating breakfast fifteen minutes later
each morning if the proposed 7:30
to 8:30 a.m. meal hour is accepted
by the food managers.
The much talked about social
dues are slowly being returned. No
money will be returned in an entry
until all those in that entry who
did not pay the five-dollar dues
pay one dollar. Those who paid
the five- dollars should have four
dollars returned.
Porter Claxton reported on
World University Service, "an organization," he said, "which supports and tries ,to promote better
educational facilities throughout
the world." Claxton suggested that
this be publicized on campus in an
effort to raise money for a "worthy
cause."
Claxton also proposed that a
Social Committee be set up to
study what can be done this spring
in the line of social activities. This
committee would be composed of
members from the various entries
interested in such a program. It
was pointed out that this would
not be handled by the DSRC. The
motion was tabled until the next
meeting.

Elections for next year's Y cabinet officials will begin next month
when the present cabinet completes
its nominations, Pete Bower, Y
president, announced this week.
Five of the several nominees will
be elected by the entire organization for next year's cabinet, which
elects its own officers. Members
may also be nominated for the cabinet by submitting a petition with
the signatures of ten members of
the Y. The current cabinet has.expanded the scope of its program to
include matters of pertinence to
the entire school and community,
Bower continued.

A representative of the United
States Marine Corps will be in
Levering Hall on April 1, 1955,
to talk with those interested in
the Platoon Leaders Class and
the Officer Candidate Course
Programs of the Marines. Further information is available in
the Placement Bureau Office in
Remsen 115.
The Placement Bureau urges
all students who have not handed
Ill their summer employment
applications to do so at once.
All those interested in term-

time employment with the concessionaires at Baltimore Oriole
home baseball games should
come to Remsen 115.

Correction
The state engineering scholarship notice which appeared on
page 1 last week was not printed
in its entirety. Following is the
full text.
Undergraduates of the School
of Engineering who wish to apply for the scholarship aid for

PAGE THREE

the academic year 1955-1956
must file an application form not
later than April 15, 1955.
This announcement applies to
those seeking renewal as well
as to those seeking scholarship
aid for the first time.
Applicants for renewal are required to fill in a simplified form
which may be procured at Dean
Roy's office. ,First time applicants, will be required to fill in
a more comprehensive form
which may be procured at Dean
Roy's office.

DONALD C. POTE will receive his B.S. degree in Mechanical
Engineering from Princeton University this June. He's been
quite active in interclub athletics—football, basketball and
baseball—and served a term as Club Athletic Director. He's
also found time to work on "The Princeton Engineer" as Associate Editor. Right now, Don is rpaking thorough plans for his
employment after graduation.

"Chuck"Noren answers:

CHARLES H. NOREN received his B.S. in Mining Engineering from the University of North
Dakota before he entered the U. S. Air Force.
Later he returned to school for an M.S.from the
Missouri School of Mines, received in 1948. During the course of his DuPont employment,Chuck
Noren has had a wide variety of job assignments. At present he is engaged in a fundamental research project concerned with commercial
explosives at Du Pont's Eastern Laboratory in
Gibbstown, N. J.

The answer to that is easy, Don,if you mean initial assignments. Generally speaking, a graduate's first assignment is
influenced by his previous training and his expressed interest
in a particulPar type of work. Whenever possible, Du Pont
oftsigns a man to the type of work he is trained for and wants
—he'll do better in any field if he's highly interested. For
example, my master's thesis was on the use of explosives,
and my first Du Pont -assignment was a study of the efficiency of explosives.
But experience on the job really constitutes new training.
You learn about other branches ofscience and engineering—
you broaden your horizons through daily contacts with
men having other skills. The result is that arbitrary divisions between technical branches gradually dissolve, and
you become ready for new assignments and new responsibilities—even outside your original field. In my own case,I
developed quite a bit of skill in mechanical and civil engineering techniques when I was called upon to supervise the
"shooting" of an experimental tunnel for the evaluation of
new explosives—even though my original training was in
mining engineering.
Of course, specialization in a definite field may be continued if the man specifically wants it and reveals a talent
for it. The best opportunities for that are in research and
development. Naturally, the value of this kind of work is
also recognized at Du Pont.
So,no matter what your initial assignment may be, Don,
Du Pont is anxious to bring out your best. A good rule to
remember is this. A graduate's first assignment is often necessarily based on his field of training and his degree, but his
subsequent progress at Du Pont is always based on his demonstrated ability.

DONALD C. POTE will receive his B.S. degree in Mechanical
Engineering from Princeton University this June. He's been
quite active in interclub athletics—football, basketball and
baseball—and served a term as Club Athletic Director. He's
also found time to work on "The Princeton Engineer" as Associate Editor. Right now, Don is rpaking thorough plans for his
employment after graduation.

"Chuck"Noren answers:

CHARLES H. NOREN received his B.S. in Mining Engineering from the University of North
Dakota before he entered the U. S. Air Force.
Later he returned to school for an M.S.from the
Missouri School of Mines, received in 1948. During the course of his DuPont employment,Chuck
Noren has had a wide variety of job assignments. At present he is engaged in a fundamental research project concerned with commercial
explosives at Du Pont's Eastern Laboratory in
Gibbstown, N. J.

The answer to that is easy, Don,if you mean initial assignments. Generally speaking, a graduate's first assignment is
influenced by his previous training and his expressed interest
in a particulPar type of work. Whenever possible, Du Pont
oftsigns a man to the type of work he is trained for and wants
—he'll do better in any field if he's highly interested. For
example, my master's thesis was on the use of explosives,
and my first Du Pont -assignment was a study of the efficiency of explosives.
But experience on the job really constitutes new training.
You learn about other branches ofscience and engineering—
you broaden your horizons through daily contacts with
men having other skills. The result is that arbitrary divisions between technical branches gradually dissolve, and
you become ready for new assignments and new responsibilities—even outside your original field. In my own case,I
developed quite a bit of skill in mechanical and civil engineering techniques when I was called upon to supervise the
"shooting" of an experimental tunnel for the evaluation of
new explosives—even though my original training was in
mining engineering.
Of course, specialization in a definite field may be continued if the man specifically wants it and reveals a talent
for it. The best opportunities for that are in research and
development. Naturally, the value of this kind of work is
also recognized at Du Pont.
So,no matter what your initial assignment may be, Don,
Du Pont is anxious to bring out your best. A good rule to
remember is this. A graduate's first assignment is often necessarily based on his field of training and his degree, but his
subsequent progress at Du Pont is always based on his demonstrated ability.

Stymies All-American;
Lacrosse Team Loses Taylor
Bob Taylor, Hopkins '54 AllAmerican, revealed Wednesday
afternoon that he will not be able
to play lacrosse for the entire
1955 season.
Taylor explained his enforced
absence by saying that doctors.had
advised him that further mishap
to an already-four-times-injured
ankle might result in serious, longterm change. One doctor, Taylor
said, emphatically warned him
against competition.
Taylor's inability to play will
force Coach Bob Scott to change
his plans, perhaps radically. Scott
was quoted earlier in the week as
saying ". .. the main (problem)
revolves around our attack ... Our
job is to fashion a solid unit around
Bob Taylor, unquestionably the
key man."
